title: Italics
description: Learn when and how to use italics effectively

questions.stem: What is the primary purpose of italics in text?

options.label: To make text look more elegant
To emphasize and distinguish specific types of content

questions.rationale: Italics serve specific functions: emphasis, distinguishing titles, foreign words, and special terminology.

questions.stem: Find the incorrect use of italics:
questions.text: The *report* was written by Dr. Smith and published in the *Journal of Science*.
questions.rationale: Common words don't need italics; only the journal title should be italicized.

questions.stem: When should italics be used for emphasis?

options.label: Frequently, to make writing more dynamic
Sparingly, only when necessary for clarity

questions.rationale: Overuse of italics for emphasis diminishes their effectiveness. Use sparingly and purposefully.

questions.text: The deadline is ______ tomorrow, not next week.
questions.hint: Consider whether italics would help clarify the meaning.
questions.rationale: Use italics for emphasis only when the meaning would be unclear without it.

questions.stem: Match each foreign phrase with its italicization rule:
questions.rationale: Foreign words and phrases are italicized unless they have become established in English usage.

questions.stem: Which sentence correctly handles foreign terms?

options.label: We need to establish a better *modus operandi*.

questions.rationale: Foreign phrases are italicized, but commonly used Latin terms like 'via' and 'etc.' are not.

questions.stem: Arrange these terms by their need for italics:
questions.instructions: Most likely to need italics to least likely:
questions.rationale: Less common foreign words need italics more than established Latin terms.
Major works (books, periodicals, films, etc.) are italicized, while shorter works use quotation marks.

questions.text: She read the article "Climate Change" in ______ magazine.
questions.hint: Consider what gets italics versus quotation marks.
questions.rationale: Magazine names are italicized, while article titles use quotation marks.

questions.text: The movie *Inception* is based on the short story "The Dream."
questions.rationale: This is actually correct - movies are italicized, short stories use quotation marks.

questions.stem: When should scientific names be italicized?
questions.rationale: Binomial nomenclature (genus and species) is always italicized in scientific writing.

questions.text: The common house cat is scientifically known as ______.
questions.hint: Remember the formatting for genus and species.
questions.rationale: Scientific binomial names are always italicized.

questions.stem: Match each term type with its formatting rule:
questions.rationale: Only formal taxonomic names require italics, not general scientific terms.

questions.stem: How should case names be formatted in legal writing?
questions.rationale: Legal case names are conventionally italicized in legal citations.

questions.text: The precedent was set in "Brown v. Board of Education" (1954).
questions.rationale: Case names should be italicized, not in quotation marks: Brown v. Board of Education.

questions.stem: When are letters or words italicized when used as examples?

options.label: When referring to the letter or word itself

questions.rationale: Letters, words, or phrases used as linguistic examples (metalinguistically) are italicized.

questions.text: The word ______ is often misspelled as "recieve."
questions.hint: Consider how to format a word being discussed as a word.
questions.rationale: Words being discussed as words themselves should be italicized.
